title: San Francisco Peaks in Arizona

description.text: This extinct stratovolcano north of Flagstaff, AZ, makes for a distinctive 3D print, made from free USGS topographical data. Here's the peak: http://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geocode=&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=59.639182,135.263672&ie=UTF8&ll=35.336974,-111.644611&spn=0.121971,0.264187&t=p&z=13 Matt Mechtley converted the height field into a printable object, with help from Sean Ragan. Matt's working on a tutorial for converting USGS topo data into printable terrain maps.

Slice up the .stl with skeinforge, etc. and print. I got some strange results with this .stl including lots of moving of the print head without extruding, and one spot about 1/3 of the way up where it tries to move the platform too far, resulting in an offset top of the peaks. I paused the print and moved the platform back into place, but will look into what caused this bug.

author: bekathwia

description.text: Not having access to any 3D scanning I decided to do some basic surface mapping the long and tedious way and came up with this tool to use as a template. The grid holes are spaced 5mm x 10mm and each hole measures 1.1mm x 4.1mm which should allow a fairly snug fit for the "depth gauge shaft" of my Chinese made electronic digital caliper to pass through. Yes, I'm fully aware that this will be a very time consuming method of mapping a surface but at least it will be reasonably effective. [EDIT] I used this tool and a digital caliper to "map" the contour of the back of my HTC Desire HD phone so I could make a tri-pod mount for it - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8039 I just did one half and then mirrored the measurements for the other half.

Print it standi upright (support feet flat on print bed)
Cut off the support feet as they are just that...to support the structure while print it to prevent it from falling over. The reason for printing this way is to minimise warping.
Fit M4 screws in the 3 round holes to act as leveling feet.
Lay the tool flat on some surface, adjust the feet so the tool sits at the angle you want. Measure the thickness with your caliper and zero it afterwards. Stick the depth gauge through each hole and measure down to your surface and record each measurement. Now, go and draw these coordinates in your design software and create your 3D surface.

For if you're trying to look around corners. As usual the o-jasper/various-physibles github contains the development versions.

• Print one stick and three corners.

  • Clear out and plastic crud where the glass goes.(down to the corners) Especially the one with
    the stick on it.

  • Clear out the holes in the bulbous things. (So putting the wire in is easy)

  • Put the corners on the mirror completely. Careful not to break it/cut yourself.

  • Find some wire to hold it together, i used steel wire but maybe nylon on kite
    wire is better.

  • Wire it together. Do not try to force the corners onto mirror in this process,
    less force to just put those on by hand.

I broke one of the arms on my beloved glasses. Instead of buying a new pair it seemed obvious to draw up some new ones and print them. I based the new frames on my existing lenses and drew those up from scratch. The arms are a slightly modified version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:128687 with the studs removed. You'll notice the hinges don't use screws. I've instead used 1.75mm PLA filament to hold the hinge together.
Printed on a Makerbot Replicator 2 with default settings at 0.1mm layer height and 205C degrees. Print time was just shy of 4 hours.

comments.text: I think I'm in over my head to tackle this as a first modelling project --- trying to figure out how to take a great design like this and retrofit it to fit the lenses of my son's broken glasses. :)  Not happening.  LOL

author: mendida

description.text:
Most UK keys are Yale or simular enough that Yale fit, say 80+%. So this customiser will allow you to copy your keys.  
Printed, and the new version fits the Yale profile (finally!). It needed a few corners filed off that were catching, but then it worked fine.

1) Compare the key again the screen, moving the sliders until it matches (align the stopper too).
2) Select "print ready > yes".
3) download and print. [0.2mm layer height and support recommended]
4) maticulously remove support, and go over with a knife / file removing any bits that may catch.
5) please leave me feedback to improve it :)

title: LED Strip-Clip for Flamewheel - Extended Version

description.text:
I did an extended version on my older clip -> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:613113 Its twice as long as before and so it will hold the doubled amount of LEDs. It's asymetrical because I wanted to have more light on the 'inside'.
The idea behind is as before, that you can fast attach and detach it. It fits very tight and does not move, but if you want to leave it at your copter for longer, I'd recommend to fixate it. On ieeekBay I found a cool little controller for the RGB LEDs, so I can change the light as I like or adjust it to the conditions. For example -> http://www.ebay.de/itm/12V-Mini-RGB-Kontroller-fur-LED-Leuchtband-/290958470411?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_77&hash=item43be79ed0b
I used an old IDE-Port cable for wiring. Printed pairwise on an Up! mini with [email protected] in about 70 minutes with little support. Hope you like it ...

description.text:
I got bored on a train ride and improved this old design. It's a replacement-part for the 4 bed holders and now
should in theory reduce wobble in not only in 1 but 2 dimensions. It's an experiment and not yet proven to work well.
(work in progress. I hope to get around to trying it when I take the machine apart anyway to replace all corners and the 4 Z-rods.)

My sons landing gear broke after a hard landing. These will nicely replace them. The pins will still remain a weak spot. You will need to rotate the first leg to have it print flat on the bed. I will update this later.
Infill of 15% honeycomb should do fine to keep it light.

title: HIC Prusa i3 Right Side Guide / Steady Rod End Stop!

description.text:
After some design changes to the Right Side Z-Axis block the rod will still pop-up every now and then. This very simple rod stop will help stop that pesky rod from moving to far up and out into open space.  
The two files are 123d Design and stl. You can change them to suit your printer if needed in 123d Design.
Very simple, undo the bolt nearest to the rod hole. Align and place the stop so the two end clip around the edges and the dome fits into the hole. Then simply place the bolt back and tighten up.

description.text: Replace the old 4.0 sticker on the back of your Jeep with a 3D version!  There are 2 types uploaded, one for single extruder, and one for dual extruders.  For dual extruder, bring each .stl in and assign a nozzle to print from.  Secure with 3M trim tape to vehicle.

Dual color prints can be made in several ways.  You can just print in one job with a color assigned to each nozzle, or the way I did it, was to print each color as a separate job and use PVC cement to bond the ABS together.  My nozzles aren't exactly level so I had dragging issues with one of my nozzles, smearing the print.

author: mikers

description.text: Yup... once in a while they break. Here is a shiny new replacement set so you can keep on flying. Unlike the easy-break OEM part, each replacement skid is a closed loop and mounts with two 3mm x 10mm screws. They are approx 3mm longer, 'cause that never hurts.  Clearance for the reduction gear is provided.

MOUNTING INSTRUCTIONS: For each of the skids:
Screw the 3mm cap head screws all the way in to the holes and strip out the thread by over-tightening with the long end of your hex key. This will make for a snug fit that will support the airframe but will allow the screws to turn somewhat freely so that you can fasten the skids to the mounting holes on the airframe. Attaching to airframe:
Mount each skid, with installed 3mm screws, to the corresponding holes on the airframe.
DO NOT to strip out the holes on the airframe
"Easy with that hex key Tex..."
Want a little snowman for decor? This is perfect for a little statue to represent your winter. The height of this snowman is around 70 mm.
I programmed this on OpenSCAD.

title: SG90 Servo Stand - TEST BED HOLDER

description.text: SG90 Servo Stand for Tower Pro Servo

UPDATED FILES AFTER MY FIRST BUILD WAS A LITTLE POOP(!) As detailed on:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:787942 Print upside down. -As shown in STLs

This Servo Stand will allow your servos to stand upright whilst you (faff) around with your Arduino AATINY85 thinking "Why the hell isn't this thing responding to SoftwareServo.H as expected?????"  
Oh the joy.

Though eventually you may find someone's code like https://digistump.com/board/index.php?topic=444.0 which stops you ripping out whatever is left of your hair. Anyways, kudos to you Mr. AMorris. Servos and ATTINY85 are cool, but what if you want to have the servos stand up on their own and rotate freely without the hand to steady them? This stand is what.

Completely free, seriously, no "if, whys or buts" - this is in the public domain - so none of that "Hey, dude you can't make profit from my work!!!" stuff.  
Make Profit. Make a silver plated one. Make a solid Gold one. Sell it to a toothless old lady for £20,000....... It doesn't matter.   
If what you care about is getting the design out to people who need it, then you make it completely free, not "open Source, with caveats" - give that stuff away for free.  
If someone wants to tool up and produce 20,000 of these babies and amortise tooling across the first run, then its probably cheaper than 3D printed, so should be cheaper and of course you can't stop other people making it cheaper so it controls the profits the "evil business" makes on it.  
You can buy this and any other design on my thingiverse page from me for £10,000 + postage, or through my US agents.  You can sell any design on my thingiverse page for £4,000 - especially in North America.  
All parts easily available are for sale.  
This makes it impossible to patent the designs I've put in open source as they are all clearly for sale in America, land of the messed up patent system. Since they are for sale, no one can patent anything I've openly divulged.  
Anyway.  
Servo Stand,  
Enjoy.

title: Modular Paper and 3D Printed lamp - Untitled
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The lamp uses PLA parts made from a 3D printer (Makerbot replicator 2) to hold together pieces of paper. My idea was to use the paper we waisted from bad prints (I come from an artschool where printing and overprinting is an issue) and to give it a "nicer" second life than traditional recycling. I wanted to showcase the beauty of some of the paper that we throw away and make something that can be shared and recreated by others. This is a work in progress all the parts can be edited and fixed to fit your needs and liking. Here is a link to download them : https://mega.co.nz/#!CNMxBZ5Z!9Rc_Y5kCzavvRuNW_1ZVBtq6IvZZSANtxPXJM3iQ5vw
Include file key Project explanation : I started to notice how much paper we waste at my art school from printing our projects. We use the printer for all sorts of things and inevitably there are mistakes: misprints, printer errors, tests etc. But the behavior that bothered me most is the attitude that we have towards the wasted paper: almost everyone throws their misprints in the rubbish. None of it is recycled. Almost all the paper is structurally intact and only has ink on it. I came to realize that all this paper tells a story and can have a certain beauty... and it just gets thrown away.   I wanted to bring attention to this by giving the paper a different sort of second life. Instead of recycling it to get rid of it like a problem, I saw it as an opportunity. I wanted to reuse the paper in a way that shows its beauty, and I wanted to develop an object that could be shared and “recreated" by others with their own paper.
I came up with a design for a modular lamp which is made out of paper held together with 3D printed parts. I chose to make a lamp because I thought that the light shining through paper would be the perfect way to showcase the allure of these rejected prints. Using 3D printed parts makes the lamp elements accessible and easy to share. There is no glue, no tape and no cutting, so it's easy for anyone to create something. The parts are reusable and are designed to be used in multiple ways. There is no right or wrong shape or design - anyone can use the parts to his or her liking and explore different designs. ￼￼

To make the same lamp the same way I did : Print each part the following amount of times :
  • Lamp peg : x8
  • Lamp branch : x8
  • Lamp holder : x1
  • Lamp clip : x40 (or less if you plan on using less - 40 is how many I printed and having extras is better)
    • The branches, holder and clips were printed 0.2mm layer thickness and with a 15% infil.
    The pegs were printed using 0.1mm thickness and 100% infil.
    It shouldn't take more than a couple hours to print everything.
  • ALSO :
    • The clips are designed to be printed vertically so remember to rotate them correctly !!! None of the parts require supports. The vertical paper to support the structure is A4 (A3 can be used to make it longer though) And for the paper to fit in the slits that are 21x3mm make sure to fold them a bit smaller so that they fit. Before your first fold I recommend you measure 17mm and keep folding it. Anyways I think that's it, if you look at the pictures everything should be easy to understand ! If you have any questions feel free to message me ! And send me pictures of your creations ! :)

After printing the calliper holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7206, I was inspired to make a holder for my tweezers and right angle. It is designed to fit my Thing-O-Matic by simply hanging over the edge of the top with a grip on the inside. Minor modification should allow it to work with a cupcake as well. My guess is that most of you do not have the same constellation of right angle and 4 tweezers, like I do, but I hope that the OpenSCAD file will help you create your own over the edge tool holder.

Just render, print, and then cut away the support material in the grip.
Cutting the support material was more difficult than I had hoped, I had tried thinner supports, only to have the GCode leave them out. :(  So you may want to experiment with the supports, and your 3D printer settings.

I am trying to combine both hot-ends into one package. All holes are M3 and the fans are 40mm for the duct and 30mm for the hot-end. I won't be able to print it for about two months, so this is still a work in progress. If you do happen to print please post your makes.

comments.text: After a few attempts, I got this printed and installed on my machine.  Rotated both parts so the down side was down and printed with support.  Tolerances are really tight on the carriage.  Bearing, v6 and chimera hotend openings on the carriage needed a bit of opening up a dremel.  Not terrible though.  The fan duct needs to be a bit narrower on the chimera side.  There's not really enough room to arrange the two hotends without coming uncomfortably close to the duct.  The openings also direct the air primarily at the side of the heater blocks.  The ducts may be better if the openings were on the bottom and angled out rather than on the sides.

If, like me, you have trouble remembering which pullchain turns on the ceiling fan and which turns on the light, attach these finials -- the dangly bits at the end of the chain... I had to look up the correct term -- and yank unerringly.   
I happened to have two differently sized pullchains, so there is a lock part for each size.

I printed these without support, which required a bit of cleanup for the light bulb's lock-pocket; with support I think they would need even more cleanup.  
Add a bit of silver paint for the light bulb's thread area, pass the chain through each object, snap the appropriately sized lock onto the end of the chain, and pull the chain back through to seat the lock.  I didn't find glue necessary, but if the lock is loose a dab might help.  
I designed these things at an arbitrary size and then scaled each to what seemed "right."  In the .stl files they are 30mm tall, you can edit the OpenSCAD source or scale in your slicing software if you prefer a different size.  Note though that while I scaled the overall objects in OpenSCAD, I did not scale the holes for the chain or the chain lock.

This is an 8 tube magnetic rack for 1.5mL tubes. These things are insanely overpriced and are a perfect thing to 3D print - the major cost is the magnets which are ~70 cents a piece. This design has little arm things that hold your tubes in place snugly and can even hold them in when upside down. I recommend using these magnets: http://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=B842 and using some epoxy to glue the magnets in. The easiest way to glue them in is to glue an outer one first, then put a tube in to hold it in place, then do the same to the third position tube, then the second one can be glued in since it will have equal magnetism to the left and right. Repeat for the rest of the rack. This design is optimized to use less plastic and prevent warping during printing, though I still recommend printing a raft just so it gets started easier. I updated this model with a different base (it now has more room for you to look at the beads when pipetting) and also a version where the tube grabbers are printed without an overhang as per suggestion in comments. Also if you are a grad student and are trying to convince your PI to buy a 3D printer - making just a few of these more than pays for the printer itsself!

title: Japan Experience: Great Torii at Miyajima

description.text:
While traveling through Japan,
we visited the Torii (gate) on the Island Miyajima.
This would be a nice structure in my pond, so I made a scale model. Information on this historical beauty:
http://visit-miyajima-japan.com/en/assets/images/ootorii1.jpg Please like before collecting! Thomas
www.3Daybreaker.blogspot.com

Printing gives a small desktop model.
Be advised, this print works also very well if scaled up to 200%. 25% infill, 0.2mm layer Update 2015-04-29: new files due to an error in the main pillar hole positioning You need 4x Qzuil
4x Qdak
2x Czuil
4x Qspar
1x all others some files have multiple objects.
"Zuilen" has all the pillars, with a designed raft, to have them stick better. to be printed red
"Binten" are the big spar and roof support to be printed red
"Black parts"are the roof and pillar tops to be printed black
"Binthalf" is a file in which the spars are cut in half, to get nicer prints. So choose which one to print. Beware: Binten has a smaller size Cspar, as the subtracted version will not fit, so do not print the single Cspar, but ue the one in BINTEN Some glueing with cyanic is needed. Be carefull ! Please like before collecting! Thomas
www.3Daybreaker.blogspot.com

author: vijayuppala

title: Flexy-Form Insole - Customizable
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I offer a CAD tool that the podiatry profession can implement right at the coal face, or "Chairside" as they like to say. No scanner required. Take measurements, enter values in OpenSCAD or Customizer, export model, print flat and heat form to fit.
  • Open source CAD (OpenSCAD).
  • Customizable insole profile to fit internal shoe size.
  • Thermoformable surface in hot water, re-form time after time.
  • Filaflex and PLA Composite.
  • Print with a single nozzle, material changes with height.
  • Integrated hinge lines.
    • The disclaimer here is that I am only providing information, this is not medically certified and is not designed to be such, but hey in many parts of the world, people walk round on planks of wood or old car tyres so everything is builder beware. Go forth and MAKE!!!

description.header: EDIT 10/06/2016 : This is pretty much superseded by my software over at http://www.gensole.com
description.text:
http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

The first step is to familiarise yourself with the drawing showing the parameters which define the profile of the insole. These are available to enter into Customizer :
  • Length
  • Heel_Radius
  • Toe_Radius
  • Inside_Width
  • Inside_Length
  • Outside_Width
  • Outside_Length
  • Instep_Offset
    • Entering valid values for these will define the profile of the insole. All of the following entries will turn on/off features of the insole:

  • Foot Pretty sure this one is self explanatory, Left or Right. Note: The insole is designed and printed upside down so please bear this in mind.

  • STL_Type has 3 values, "Joined", "Upper" and "Lower".
    This means you have the choice of rendering the model into it's constituent models in-case your slicer prefers separate STL's (S3D, Slic3r, Cura etc) or modifier meshes (Slic3r) to vary the infill etc for the different layers. Some slicers, such as Cura have a modify at Z plugin which you may want to use. Use could use dual extrusion too or change filament partway through the model, it's your choice, depending on your printer/slicer, more information below in the "Printing" section.

  • Lattice turns on the Thermoform mesh. I initially thought this might be required but the insole forms well if printed without the little holes, but I left the code in anyway.

  • Number_of_Hinge_Lines This creates breaks in the rigid layers of the insole so it can bend with your foot and shoe. The Joint-Line is created between P3 and P4 and the Hinge-lines are offset from this and they are each spaced 10mm apart.

  • Thickness The total thickness of the insole.

  • Rigid_Layer_Thickness defines how much of the insole is made up of the thermoformable rigid material (PLA).

  • Chamfer_Width Not an exact value in mm but a parameter to control the size of the feather edge around the insole. Because this feather edge is flexible it can be useful to print slightly oversize and the profile will curl up inside the shoe for a good fit.

If you have removable insoles already in your shoes then remove them, lay them down flat on a piece of paper or card and trace around the profile so you can take measurements. Another way is to cut out a piece of stiff card so that you can get it to fit nicely inside your shoe and then trace around this onto some paper.

  • You will need to mark on the profile that you have just traced, the points P1 through to P5 which are shown on my drawing. I attach some examples of some Pulman shoe insoles that I traced around and marked up.

  • Draw the datum line of the insole beween P1 and P2 which are points on the extreme ends of the insole that define the length. This will be an important line which will help you measure all the dimensions.

  • Draw lines perpendicular from the central datum line out to points P3,P4 and P5.

  • Mark the centres of the Toe Radius and the Heel Radius on the datum line.

  • Now that all the geometry of the insole is defined, it is time to take the measurements in mm from your marked out drawing. It is easier to take the length measurements along the datum line to the intersecting lines from P3 and P4.

There are a variety of options depending on your slicer of choice. Print in flexible material for the lower section on the print bed and PLA for the upper. Note the insole is printed upside down compared to the actual use.

  • Pause at Z height and change the material.

  • You can use dual extrusion for the different materials.
    • The best bond between the materials is achieved if the top shell of the flexible material (e.g. Filaflex) has a solid layer printed and the lower shell of the PLA is also solid. This has the most surface area contact. In fact for strength I would suggest you print the PLA near solid. You can use the following slicer options :

  • Cura - Export the "Joined" stl from customizer and use the Tweak at Z height plugin enabled to change the density of the last layer of Filaflex and upwards to solid.

  • Simplify3D - Export the "Upper" and "Lower" stls from customizer. Import into Simplify3D and slice each stl with separate processes. One low infill density for the Filaflex and high density for the PLA.

  • Slic3r - Export both the "Joined" and "Upper" stl from Customizer. Slice the "Joined" stl with a low density and use the Upper as a "Modifier Mesh" with a higher density.

Prepare the recipient by getting them to wear a sock to protect foot from the heat.
Thermoforming is a case of heating up a kettle of boiling water and pouring this onto a baking tray with the insole placed on top. After about 20 seconds the PLA will be really soft. Use a spatula, or tongues to remove the insole from the hot water. At this stage best to wear gloves or use a towel placed between your hands and the insole. You can now form the insole to the bottom of the recipients foot.

I want to make the thermoforming process less "skill" based and more reliable so I am reaching out to makers for inspiration that can be implemented cheaply and simply. Some initial ideas:
  • Place insole under recipients foot on top of some foam block, (maybe memory foam), then push down to form insole.
  • Put some rice/lentils etc or dry sand in a shoe box and place the insole on top then stand on it to form.

title: 96 well plate / 0.2 mL strip tube Magnet Rack

description.text:
NEW AND IMPROVED. This is a magnet holder for magnetic bead separation for either a 96 well plate - or a 96 well plate with the wells cut out can be taped on top to hold 8 tube strips. The magnets for this new version must be custom ordered (KJ magnets) but it is well worth it for the improved performance. Now beads are pulled up and to the side making it much easier to pipette out the contents without disturbing the beads. The magnet specs are: Custom NdFeB Block Magnet, Part No. 4C3M04
2.750" x 0.188" x 0.188" thick
Grade N42, Nickel (Ni-Cu-Ni) Plated, magnetized through 0.188 in thickness
Qty 24 @ $6.35 each (minimum order quantity) I am not sure if that order number will stay in the system though. The minimum order makes 4 magnet racks, so if you need less - team up with another group. For tube racks just cut the top rings off of a 96-well plate and tape it to magnet rack (shown in photos). NOTE: The first version uses available magnets (http://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=BZ082), not custom order, but pulls beads to the bottom, not the side. The new version (303) performs much better and is recommended.

text = Zander Dhondt Be HAPPY

My quick take on a commercial product that no longer seems to be available.   
You can customize the radius of the bead and the diameter of the opening by changing the values of beadrad and opendia and regenerating the .stl file.  
The large end of the opening tends to sag during printing, but it does still work.  I could keep the differenced-out portions of the "wings" so that I could print it on end instead of flat, but don't have the inclination at the moment... .  
This might be even more effective if printed in flexible plastic, but I don't have any and have never tried any, so I can't say for certain.

I loaded the .stl into Reptier-Host, rotated it by 90 degrees around X, then used the "lay flat" function to make sure it was properly oriented.  
The opening goes towards the corner of the surfaces you're caulking; pull toward you while extruding caulk with the gun at an angle of between 45 and 90 degrees.  You'll get the hang of it pretty quickly.

author: hackermagnet

description.text: This is a quick and simple light diffuser for the common IKEA "Ledberg" LED strips. When printed using translucent filament, it turns the LED strips into coloured mood lights!

This needs to be printed vertically upwards. I found good results when printing at a resolution of 0.3mm, with a 0.4mm nozzle. The printer I use at home is the Printrbot Simple Metal, but it should work just as well on any 3D printer.  
You will need to print 4 of these to cover 1 LED strip. I don't recommend scaling this upwards vertically as it may warp with too much height.  
Note that since this is a light diffuser, it MUST be printed with translucent filament. If you use opaque filament, the light won't shine through.

description.text:
Please see V2 instead http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:820001 This is a large Seven Segment LED display that you can use to create your own clocks, scoreboards, whatever. This initial version is customizable, but the SCAD is a mess. SCAD file produces two parts:
Case is the item that separates each segment.
Lens are the items that can optionally be printed in the case. Still working best combination of materials for LED diffusion. Default STL file is a 200mm height character, which fits on a Flashforge or clone bed.
Multiple ways to use the parts:

Either:
  • Print just the case, and use a sheet of diffusion material (e.g., parchment sheet or Rosco Cinegel 3000, which produces great results) over the case.
  • Make the lens element really small (one or two layers) and print the case and lens as one piece.

Either:
  • Print the case and lens in one pass with two colors (e.g., white lens and black case) - make sure the lens is thin (<0.6mm)
  • Print the case in a plastic like ABS, and print the lens in a plastic like PETG. (This is what I am trying to get correct.)

title: Garmin Nuvi 610 T motorcycle mounting box

description.text:
Some time ago I made a holder / mounting-box for my GPS unit due to the non-existence of units specific to different GPS makes/models. Back then I used a metal elecronics enclosure but it was still not ideal or professional looking although it didn't look too bad and did the job.
Enter the 3D printer...
Now I was able to design a brand new custom box which will look 100 times better and also be easier to use.
The large lower section is at this stage necessary to accomodate the power cable attachment that clips onto the GPS unit.
I plan to eliminate the standard power cable and therefore the bulky lower box section. I want to integrate a power connector into the base of the holder and thereby eliminating the unsightly standard power cable. I can't "hide" the standard cable as I also use it in my car. Then I can leave it in the car permanently.

I cut the lower tray section in 2 to allow for printing without support material. I incorporated a lip/groove feature to allow fo accurate mating of the two halves.
Once all is printed and the tay halves glued together just snap the 2 hinge pins of the lid/cover into their holes in the sides of the tray. The front has a snap hook feature to keep the cover closed.

description.text:
Removes cuttings from the work surface, collect them in the back.
This moves the cuttings by both blowing from the front and pulling air from the back. The dust case has a drop so cuttings go down and air goes up. The blower needs a minimal filter.

obtain:
1) blower https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11270
2) birch plywood
3) 1.125" hose http://www.homedepot.com/p/Watts-1-1-8-in-I-D-x-6-ft-PVC-Bilge-and-Pump-Hose-HSBBO6/204407907
4) 12 Volt supply. 3D print the hose adaptors
laser cut the box and cover.
Assemble the box and glue. Do not glue cover, it is a friction fit.
counter sink the screw holes for the blower
mount the blower to the box with Qty 3 #8-32 x 1-1/2 in or longer flat-head machine screws and nuts or button head and wood inserts. Use the "rolandfanback.dxf" as a way to attach a filter.
Mount the box to the roland with the Qty 2 screws on the back plate.
Assemble the blower adaptor, hose and diverter for the hose assembly.
Wire the blower to a 12 supply. more here... http://wiki.makeitlabs.com/projects/roland-mill-upgrade

PLA seems to hold up strength wise, but ABS might be better for more serious 4 wheeling.

Created a basic rigidbot motherboard case.  I used spacers to elevate the board and drilled some holes for airflow.  Plenty of room to add fan.  Also the extension under the cables allows to attach cable supports since the cables (particularity the power cable) are heavy and put stress on the connection on the board.  I found just the extension helps but additional support would be a good idea.  Yes I know the bolts I used were too long but they allow for air flow at least.

I designed these boxes to keep small things, like pills, organized. Why not speices when camping.The boxes are 44 mm wide and 25 mm high. You can stack as many boxes as you like, it is not necessary to use the bottom box, but it looks more complete with that box. The threads are generated using Mike Thompsons nut and bolt factory in Openscad, many thanks for that piece of code. Have fun and print your own stack. The stl files are switched to files with higher resolution in the cylinder walls and 1.5 mm side walls giving no fill in the walls.
If you find my design useful please give me a TIP
A good idea is to grease the threads with some vaseline and give them a good workout.

description.text:
I've experienced the 3D virtual reality googles Oculus Rift now for 4 weeks and had one particular problem:
How can I find the correct key that I need on my keyboard when I don't see anything? So I came up with a cheap €12 USB numerical pad and some on-top keys which have clear differences in haptics and feelings. I simply glued those onto the numpad and voilá here is my low-cost Oculus Rift tactile keyboard. Simply configurated the most common commands to the respective keys and practiced a bit. Works great for me! :-)
Simply use glue to attach the tops onto the different keys, preferrable try to place similar icons away from each other.

title: Kossel Mini adjustable heated bed mount for 220mm bed

description.text:
UPDATE July 2015: v2 version is much easier to setup - has one hole to mount to kossel mini frame and adjustable hole for heatbed mount. Will provide photos later
  • Used for mounting 220mm round heatbed to kossel mini frame. Not a nice design but it works :-)
  • Can probably be used for other sizes as well
  • Still work in progress, so maybe I will make some changes in future.
  • Leaves enough space for RAMPS to be put under HB (not tested yet)
    • Required hardware:
  • 3pcs M3 nuts
  • 3pcs M3x8 bolts (thing to frame)
  • 3 pcs M3x16 bolts (heatbed to thing)
    • Comments and remixes welcome.

Photos are in (some kind of) chronological order
  • Print 3 pieces in ABS (better thermal resistance)
  • Redrill the holes with 3mm drill if needed
  • Mount with M3x8mm bolts to kossel frame - hand tighten
  • Place heatbed and adjust mounts
  • Tighten the mounts
  • Mount heatbed (use of heat insulation like cork recommended)

Hello,
I bought the cheapest thing they had - which is a roll 1 meter * 0,5 meters with 3mm thickness. It is used for thermal insulation, vibration damping or for hobby projects. title: M3, M4, M5, M6, M7, M8, M10 nut placeholder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I often need some kind of regular (M3, M4, ...) nuts to create things, that should be buildable without glue but with screws. And it's annoying to create the needed space for the nuts every time. So bit by bit I'll add the regular Mx-Nuts. a = side length, b = diameter side-to-side, c = diameter edge-to-edge, d = height (all units are in millimeters mm) M3: a = 3.175, b = 5.5, c = 6.351, d = 2.4
M4: a = 4.04, b = 6.997, c = 8.08, d = 3.2
M5: a = 4.619, b = 8, c = 9.238, d = 4
M6: a = 5.774, b = 10, c = 11.548, d = 5
M7: a = 6.351, b = 11, c = 12.702, d = 5.5
M8: a = 7.506, b = 13, c = 15.012, d = 6.5
M10: a = 9.815, b = 17, c = 19.63, d = 8 I'm using the dimensions from http://zjpenghong.en.alibaba.com/product/632279128-209923341/DIN_934_Hex_Nut_Size_M4_Nuts_Nut_and_Bolt_Bolts_Nuts_Low_Carbon_Steel_Stainless_Steel.html .

This is a case that holds an ATX power supply and a Raspberry Pi Model B (though others may fit). It's intended to make a nice little package to put beside your printer for powering an Octoprint server and PrintrBot with heated bed. There are two versions- a fully assembled one, and a kit made of pieces. The fully-assembled model is a very difficult print (it uses most of the build volume of a Metal Plus and requires 2-3 days). The kit is much easier to print, and the pieces can be superglued together easily. I have also included separate STL files for all the pieces. For more information on this project, go to:
http://quinndunki.com/blondihacks/?p=2292

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aAo87C665Tk

This thing is desinged to be a toy called a Newton's crade. What you do is you lift up a ball at one end, and the ball on the other end will recive the energy from the ball you lifted up, while the three in the middle don't move! There are other tricks you can do with this, such as lifting up two balls and two balls will recive the momentum. If you are going to print this, look at the instructions for how to print! If you don't follow them, this toy won't work. This thing was made in Open SCAD in two parts. The first one was the cradle. The code for that is below:
cube([50,45,5]);
difference() {
cube([50,5,50]);
translate([5,0,0])cube([40,5,45]);
translate([5,0,47])rotate([-90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);
translate([15,0,47])rotate([-90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);
translate([25,0,47])rotate([-90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);
translate([35,0,47])rotate([-90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);
translate([45,0,47])rotate([-90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);
translate([4,0,47.5])cube([2,45,5]);
translate([14,0,47.5])cube([2,45,5]);
translate([24,0,47.5])cube([2,45,5]);
translate([34,0,47.5])cube([2,45,5]);
translate([44,0,47.5])cube([2,45,5]);
}
difference() {
translate([0,40,0])cube([50,5,50]);
translate([5,40,0])cube([40,5,45]);
translate([5,0,47])rotate([-90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);
translate([15,0,47])rotate([-90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);
translate([25,0,47])rotate([-90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);
translate([35,0,47])rotate([-90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);
translate([45,0,47])rotate([-90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);
translate([4,0,47.5])cube([2,45,5]);
translate([14,0,47.5])cube([2,45,5]);
translate([24,0,47.5])cube([2,45,5]);
translate([34,0,47.5])cube([2,45,5]);
translate([44,0,47.5])cube([2,45,5]);
}
The second part are the balls. The code is for only one ball, you you must print this STL 5 times. The code for that is below:
translate([-40,-10,0])sphere(5);
translate([-40,-10,0])rotate([30,0,0])cylinder(35,1,1);
translate([-40,-10,0])rotate([-30,0,0])cylinder(35,1,1);
translate([0,23,30])translate([-40,-10,0])rotate([90,0,0])cylinder(45,1,1,$fn=100);

To get this thing to work, you must first print out the STL file called "Newton's cradle" once. Then print the STL called "Newton's cradle ball" five times. After those are printed, put the balls into the groves on the stand. Now it's ready to use!

author: Ohio3wheels

description.text:
I wanted to mount a dial indicator to the X-axis bars to make sure my bed was as level as I could get it. The dial indicator I got isn't anything fancy: http://www.harborfreight.com/1-inch-travel-machinists-dial-indicator-623.html Key design points:
  • can't put something between bars because of belts
  • use print bed surface for flat edge of mount
  • make dial mount reusable
    • I got a 1/4 in bolt to mount the dial. Note that the dial mount allows for slop in dial indicator's mounting hole.
Buy one 1/4"-20 1" bolt and matching nut.

Print preferred model.  If you pick unsupported, print with support.  If printing model with support, after print remove support from area that goes on the X axis mount and where the dial would sit flush with the print (2 places, see bottom of print in recess).

Mount dial so back is flush with where print attached to print bed.
Use Z adjustment to move so dial is in a good position to measure height from print bed (metal) and follow calibration steps documented for the printer.

When I watch TV on my iPad I constantly hold my hand behind the speaker so I can actually hear it. This morning I made this awesome reflector on my 3D printer that magnetically connects to my iPad 3. It worked so well tonight that I actually had to turn down the volume. I had to share it with you.

Some assembly required and magnets not included. Print it in two halves and glue the halves together. You will need two magnets and they can be found here. http://www.gaussboys.com/store/index.php/c0303.html Superglue or hot glue works great. Just make sure you put them in the right way so they stick to the iPad. It should work on the iPad 2, iPad 3, and iPad 4. Not tested with the iPad mini.

description.text:
I needed a stand for my RB Fender & didn't feel like biking to the store. I also couldn't find something quick & easy on Thingiverse, so made this.  
My girlfriend broke a floor standing lamp (from Target?) a few months ago, but of course I kept the pieces - which came in handy as support legs. They are threaded at ~1mm between each thread and ~12.5mm diameter - so adjust the stand for whatever you have lying around.  
If you use poster putty (or modify the design) you should only need the GuitarStand.stl, but for added stability I made a little clip to leave permanently attached to the guitar (inspired by the other more complicated and much better designed guitar stand by juniortan).
Printed at 3-4 shells 5-15% infill

title: Soldering spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Soldering Spool Holder Info  
1-Print All Parts  
2- Find a used Blade From an exacto or any other blade from a disposable Blade knife.  
3- Bring down the blade to about 10 mm and if you have the dexterity make it a     triangle shape (be careful not to hurt yourself)  
4-Use a scalpel or any other knife you do not mind heating the tip of it and after heating it, you use it to make a cavity that will receive the blade that you have prepared.  
5-Insert the blade and use some glue to fix it there (I used Kafuter UV Glue, you can get some from EBay and also the UV Flashlight)  
6-you will need to sand just a bit the shaft from Shaft "B" to have a snug fit, for those who wonder why I made a groove and slut in Shaft "A" ,it is to make it easier to assemble both shaft together as there is no air pressure staying inside ...  
7-To use take as much solder as you need then hold the spool and pull down the solder on the Sharp edge of the Blade... Careful again not to put your fingers on the sharp edge...  
Enjoy!

comments.text:
Dear Slackite,
Thank you for your comment.
The tip of the switch is bonded inside the ball with a polyurethane adhesive..
The ball is clipped into the cup (the 4 "notches" in the cup allow the necessary elasticity).
Ball and cup are 3D printed, with a clearance of 0.2 mm between the two surfaces.
The print quality is sufficient to allow a quite smooth rotation.
Best regards

Best regards

description.text: I know I know! , Rack mounting a Pi? seems kinda ridiculous. But I had occasion recently where I needed a Pi acting as a Wireless Access point controller, and the best place to put it was on the rack. So I Remixed the awesome Sleeve Case for Raspberry Pi B+ by Walter and came up with this. Its a bit silly, but if you need a Pi acting as a Router on a stick , or a VPN server, or Wifi AP controller, or any number of other things where the inexpensive Pi is a great solution, then this case might be helpful.

comments.text: First off, this is not silly.  I have 60+ pi's all over the place in server rooms that act as proxy's for our Zabbix central server.  I've been double sticking/velcroing them to the racks.  I printed a few of these to test, they work "ALMOST" perfect for me.   I need a bit more room  to access the GPIO and stuff a small DHT11 and Relay in there and it will be perfect.  Thanks for including the design files.  Now I just need to learn how to use a model editing program.  Any recommendation on software? Preferable free and/or sub $200.

author: amarvinas

title: Fan scoop for Rostock Max printer

description.text: This is a scoop that helps direct air from a fan to cool down a part being printed on a Rostock Max printer.

This part can be challenging to print well. I used Kisslicer and its support structure feature to hold up the top of the scoop's dome but the scoop can get a little torn up removing that supporting material.   
Get a 50mm fan and use 3 zip ties for attaching the scoop to the side of the fan where it blows. Make sure the open quarter of the scoop is on the same corner as where the wires come out of it. To attach the fan and scoop to the printer, put in a single slender screw into the corner where the wires exit the fan and screw it down into the tiny hole in between two sets of arms.   
I run the fan at about %40 speed but that'll depend on your configuration and the power of your fan. Any higher and my bed and extruder can't keep themselves hot enough.   
If you are printing something really big on your platform, there is a chance that the fan could bump into one of the axis extrusions but I think that switching to a smaller 25mm fan might eliminate that problem.   
I currently am just using one of these but may add a second one on the other side. If you have heat issues with your parts, you could even add a third fan.   
EDIT: Try mounting this on a side where you don't have the reel mounted. If you don't, when printing large parts, the fan can bump into the reel mount.

comments.text: I scaled this object by a factor of .8 with Cura and successfully used it with a 40mm fan. It worked great, and the holes were still the right size too.

description.text:
This is a scratch made Marlin Firmware for the S-508 3D Printer Kit (Prusa i3) sold on many Chinese websites. This is not the original firmware. And i am not a developer of the Kit.
But this is better than the original firmware, which had many flaws. Changes include the possibility to heat the extruder up to 260degrees and the hot bed up to 115degrees which are necessary for proper ABS extrusion.
Stepping has been improved too. S-508 3D Printer Kit (Prusa i3) is powered by motherboard MKS GEN V1.1
It is a combination of Arduino MEGA2560 plus RAMPS1.4 and A4988 drivers. The firmware has been tested before sharing it with you. I hope it will be useful to somebody who needs it.

This is a scratch made Marlin Firmware for the S-508 3D Printer Kit (Prusa i3) sold on many Chinese websites. This is not the original firmware. And i am not a developer of the Kit.
But this is better than the original firmware, which had many flaws. Changes include the possibility to heat the extruder up to 260degrees and the hot bed up to 115degrees which are necessary for proper ABS extrusion.
Stepping has been improved too. S-508 3D Printer Kit (Prusa i3) is powered by motherboard MKS GEN V1.1
It is a combination of Arduino MEGA2560 plus RAMPS1.4 and A4988 drivers. The firmware has been tested before sharing it with you. I hope it will be useful to somebody who needs it. Installation Instructions:

• Download Arduino from http://arduino.cc/en/Main/Software.
  • Open /Marlin/Marlin.ino with the Arduino IDE
  • set your Boardtype to "Arduino Mega 2560" and select the coresponding serial interface
  • upload the Firmware ( File->Upload )

description.text:
This is my attempt to break up 3d Hub's Marvin to make dual colors.  
Please note that by very simple editing of the scad file you could choose to include different body/suit parts in each stl for different multicolor desires.  See instructions or scad comments for further details.

By editing the single vector at the top of the attached .scad file you can customize which of the follow body elements are in your stl: legs, helmet, head, ear cylinders, ear hemispheres, @ keychain loop.  Once you've exported the first file, change "Nozzle" to 2 and export again for the complimentary body elements.  
Want the legs to match the face, but not the helmet?  Done.  Both ear pieces the same color? Easy peasy.  
Thanks to no error checking you can also remove a body component entirely.  Mark that element as "2" in the vector and it will not show up in either stl (I'm looking at you keychain loop).  It's a feature ;-).

so being a fan of the Ben heck show i couldn't help but notice that his replicator has a top mount spooler set on it. I first checked to see if he had the files up but didn't seem to. (insert an Australian Steve Irwin accent) So I started my search out in the Thingiverse jungle. I looked high and low but alas i couldn't find any. So I designed one of my own.  
right now the way I've built this it just sits on top of the printer; and my version is just a few millimeters longer than the one I've uploaded

when you lasercut this be sure to have your laser settings set to outside, i forgot to do this when i made mine and my captive nuts,well, weren't captive.  
in order to put this together you'll need four 10 mm screws and four matching nuts, also a wooden dowel that's about 19 inches long. Press fit the wooden rods into one of the two side panels, not both as you wont be able to get it over your machine properly.  
once you've done this take two 10 mm screws and screw together in the captive nut holes. slide the newly built but incomplete spool holder in between the wiring for your extruder nozzle, take a look at the picture to see what i mean; and finish up by press fitting the second side panel on and screw it together.

author: mamodom

description.text:
This is my rendition of Schlotzz's Bowden extruder for 3D printing. I elected to modify his design a little. I added a thumb lever to the idler arm. I also knocked out a little bit of the tube areas so I could add a M4 nut to the tube to hold it in place instead of the typical PTFE tubing holder. The poor mans method! Please take a look. Enjoy - share! and of course all credit goes to Schlotzz for given me the original design! Thanks
~Coog

Be sure to run a 1.75-ish mm round tool through the PTFE that has been threaded by the M4 nut. This will re-open the passage so the filament can slip through it. I use a tiny flathead scewdriver that comes in a micro-screwdriver set for glasses. Just use one that is the right size. Then take a piece of your filament and slide it through with the nuts in place. If it moves freely then your safe. I also added a picture - although it is squished - of the four units I just made in preparation for the Kraken printhead I am mounting soon. Stay tuned for things that I designed and printed for the Kraken to be mounted on a standard Prusa i3 printer. See you all soon!
~Coog
